skill.name: transformers
skill.description: This skill should be used when working with pre-trained transformer models for natural language processing, computer vision, audio, or multimodal tasks. Use for text generation, classification, question answering, translation, summarization, image classification, object detection, speech recognition, and fine-tuning models on custom datasets.
skill.summary: Expert guidance for using Hugging Face Transformers library for NLP, vision, and audio tasks
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and reference materials for the Hugging Face Transformers library. All static findings are false positives: backtick detections are markdown code blocks in documentation, eval references are PyTorch model.eval() method calls, and network references are documentation URLs. No executable code, command execution, or security risks present.

content.user_title: Master Hugging Face Transformers for AI Development
content.value_statement: Working with transformer models requires understanding pipelines, tokenization, and fine-tuning workflows. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for using the Hugging Face Transformers library across NLP, computer vision, and audio tasks with best practices and code examples.
actual_capabilities: Load and manage pre-trained transformer models from Hugging Face Hub
Perform inference using pipeline API for text, vision, and audio tasks
Generate text with various decoding strategies and sampling methods
Fine-tune models on custom datasets using Trainer API
Handle tokenization, padding, and preprocessing for model inputs
Configure device placement, precision, and memory optimization
limitations: Requires Hugging Face Transformers library installation and dependencies
Does not include model training from scratch, only fine-tuning
Performance optimization depends on available hardware and CUDA support
Authentication required for accessing gated models on Hugging Face Hub

use_cases.title: Text Classification with Pre-trained Models
use_cases.description: Use pipeline API to classify text for sentiment analysis, spam detection, or topic categorization without writing custom preprocessing code.

use_cases.title: Fine-tune Language Models for Domain Tasks
use_cases.description: Adapt pre-trained models to specialized domains like medical or legal text by fine-tuning on custom datasets using the Trainer API.

use_cases.title: Build Conversational AI with Text Generation
use_cases.description: Generate human-like text responses using GPT-style models with control over temperature, top-k, and top-p sampling parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Load a Pre-trained Model for Inference
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to load the BERT base model for text classification and run inference on a sample sentence
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginner task: loading a model and performing basic inference

prompt_templates.title: Generate Text with Custom Parameters
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me generate creative text using GPT-2 with temperature 0.8 and top-p sampling of 0.9
prompt_templates.scenario: Intermediate task: text generation with custom decoding strategies

prompt_templates.title: Fine-tune Model on Custom Dataset
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me through fine-tuning DistilBERT on my CSV dataset with sentiment labels using the Trainer API
prompt_templates.scenario: Advanced task: custom dataset fine-tuning with training loop

prompt_templates.title: Optimize Model for Production Deployment
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to quantize and optimize a transformer model for faster inference with reduced memory usage
prompt_templates.scenario: Expert task: model optimization for production environments

output_examples.input: Show me how to load a pre-trained model for sentiment analysis
output_examples.output:
I can help you load a sentiment analysis model. Here is the code using the pipeline API:

from transformers import pipeline

classifier = pipeline("sentiment-analysis")
result = classifier("I love this product!")

This will output: [{'label': 'POSITIVE', 'score': 0.9998}]

The pipeline automatically downloads and caches the default model (distilbert-base-uncased-finetuned-sst-2-english) and handles tokenization for you.

output_examples.input: Help me fine-tune a model on my custom dataset
output_examples.output:
I will guide you through the fine-tuning process:

1. First, prepare your dataset using the datasets library
2. Load the pre-trained model and tokenizer
3. Create a data collator for batching
4. Set up TrainingArguments with learning rate, batch size, and epochs
5. Initialize the Trainer with your model, datasets, and arguments
6. Call trainer.train() to start fine-tuning

Let me show you the complete code with your dataset structure.

best_practices: Use AutoModel classes instead of specific model architectures for better compatibility
Enable device_map auto for automatic GPU memory management with large models
Cache downloaded models locally to avoid repeated downloads during development
anti_patterns: Loading models without specifying torch_dtype can cause memory issues with large models
Forgetting to call tokenizer with return_tensors parameter leads to type errors
Using pipeline API for batch processing without batching parameter is inefficient

faq.question: How do I authenticate to access gated models on Hugging Face Hub?
faq.answer: Use the huggingface_hub.login() function and enter your access token when prompted. You can get tokens from https://huggingface.co/settings/tokens. Alternatively, set the HUGGINGFACE_TOKEN environment variable.

faq.question: What is the difference between AutoModel and AutoModelForCausalLM?
faq.answer: AutoModel loads the base model without a task-specific head, while AutoModelForCausalLM adds a language modeling head for text generation. Use AutoModel for feature extraction and AutoModelForCausalLM for GPT-style generation tasks.

faq.question: How can I reduce memory usage when loading large models?
faq.answer: Use device_map auto for automatic layer distribution across devices, set torch_dtype to torch.float16 or torch.bfloat16 for reduced precision, or use load_in_8bit and load_in_4bit quantization options.

faq.question: Why does my model give different outputs each time I run generation?
faq.answer: Text generation uses sampling by default which introduces randomness. Set do_sample to False for greedy decoding, or use a fixed random seed with torch.manual_seed for reproducible sampling results.

faq.question: What is the best way to process batches of text for inference?
faq.answer: Use the pipeline API with the batch_size parameter for automatic batching. For manual processing, tokenize all inputs together with padding enabled and pass the batch to the model in one forward pass.

faq.question: How do I choose the right model for my task?
faq.answer: Check the Hugging Face model hub and filter by task type. For speed, use distilled models like DistilBERT. For accuracy, use larger base models like BERT-large. For specific domains, search for domain-specific fine-tuned models.
